conclusion: To determine the work done by the gas from state B to state C, we need to understand the process occurring between these two states.

Since the problem does not specify whether this process is adiabatic, isothermal, or another type, we will assume it is an isobaric (constant pressure) process because no information suggests otherwise.
State B: \( P_B = 2 \times 10^5 \text{ Pa} \), \( V_B = 2 \times 10^{-3} \text{ m}^3 \)
State C: \( P_C = 2 \times 10^5 \text{ Pa} \), \( V_C = 3 \times 10^{-3} \text{ m}^3 \)
The work done by the gas during an isobaric process can be calculated using the formula: \( W = P \Delta V \) where \( P \) is the constant pressure and \( \Delta V \) is the change in volume.
Calculate the change in volume (\(\Delta V\)): \(\Delta V = V_C - V_B = 1 \times 10^{-3} \text{ m}^3\)
Calculate the work done: \( W = P \cdot \Delta V = 200 \text{ J} \)
